quoteFirst: (1) Tel el-Yehudîyeh or Onion.—Take the train from Cairo at 10 A.M., reaching Shibîn el-Qanâter at 12.25. Leave Shibîn el-Qanâter at
quoteLast: , reaching Cairo at 6.50. Donkeys can be procured at Shibîn, but it is a pleasant walk of a mile and a half through the fields (towards the south-east) to the Tel.
title: The Egypt of the Hebrews and Herodotos
author: Sayce, A. H. (Archibald Henry), 1845-1933

quoteFirst: We will assume the day's receipt of freight finished, and most of the cars loaded.
quoteLast: the house will be "pulled," that is, those cars already loaded will be taken away, and an empty "string" of cars put in their place. An hour later, this "string" will in turn be loaded and taken out, and the operation repeated, until all the day's receipt of freight is loaded.
title: The American Railway: Its Construction, Development, Management, and Appliances
author: Clarke, Thomas Curtis, 1827-1901; Cooley, Thomas McIntyre, 1824-1898 [Author of introduction, etc.]

quoteFirst: The type really varies at Tiflis according to the season of the year. In June--as in the mean equality from the whole year--there is a well marked double period; there is a principal minimum at 2 p.m. and a secondary one about 4 a.m.; a principal maximum about 9 a.m. and a secondary one
quoteLast: In December, however, only a single period is recognizable, with a minimum about 8 a.m. and a maximum about 7 p.m. The type of diurnal inequality seen at the Cape of Good Hope does not differ much from that seen at Batavia. Only a single period is clearly shown.
title:
Encyclopaedia Britannica, 11th Edition, "McKinley, William" to "Magnetism, Terrestrial"
Volume 17, Slice 3
author: Various

quoteFirst: My friend, having some slight ailment, I had driven out alone with our native servant, and we made a long tour, returning
quoteLast: past Ludlow Castle, of famous Mutiny memory, and still--in the year 1891--a Government bungalow.
title: Seen and Unseen
author: Bates, E. Katherine (Emily Katherine)

quoteFirst: The situation was saved by the arrival
quoteLast: of the 22nd Brigade, which had been hurried up from Bailleul in motor-buses. This brigade now took over the Household Cavalry position at Zwartelen, while the 2nd K.R.R.
title:
The First Seven Divisions
Being a Detailed Account of the Fighting from Mons to Ypres
author: Hamilton, Ernest, Lord, 1858-1939

quoteFirst: I have wanted him to do it absolutely on his own, and I could not emphasize this better than by coming right away to Mudros. Back to the _Triad_ by 1 p.m. No news. Weighed anchor at once, steaming for Imbros, where we cast anchor at
quoteLast: Freddie Maitland has arrived here, like a breath of air from home, to be once more my A.D.C.; his features wreathed in the well-known, friendly smile.
title: Gallipoli Diary,  Volume 1
author: Hamilton, Ian, 1853-1947

quoteFirst: Rifle fire, however, prevented this, and the wounded officer and Lieut. Turnbull and the orderly were unable to get away from the trenches for many hours.
quoteLast: they made an attempt in the course of which the wounded officer received a further wound and Lieut. Turnbull was shot in the lung. Of this he died four days later notwithstanding the utmost efforts made on his behalf by his colleagues, Capt. Bickerton and Lieut. Haynes.
title: The Roll of Honour, Volume 1
author: Ruvigny et Raineval, Melville Henry Massue, marquis de, 1868-1921

quoteFirst: This vessel had on board masts, spars, and a complete set of rigging, for the United States brig Bainbridge, lately obliged to cut away her masts in a gale at Aspinwall. Nine prisoners. At
quoteLast: , the prize being well on fire, steamed on our course.

quoteFirst: A small pine-tree was picked up much shattered by the ice. In the afternoon of the 30th, a very dense fog came on; and,
quoteLast: , when sailing before a fresh breeze, we were suddenly involved in a heavy stream of ice. Considerable difficulty was experienced in steering through the narrow channels between the different masses in this foggy weather, and the ship received several severe blows.
title: Narrative of a Journey to the Shores of the Polar Sea, in the Years 1819-20-21-22, Volume 1
author: Franklin, John, 1786-1847

quoteFirst: We left Delhi again at
quoteLast: , after loitering about the city for a short time, among the teeming bazaars, some parts of which were picturesque and “Eastern” enough. Outside the city walls, the country was ruined and dilapidated in the extreme; demolished houses and wasted gardens telling their tale of the loss of Delhi, and our struggle for its recapture.
title: Diary of a Pedestrian in Cashmere and Thibet
author: Knight, W. H. (William Henry)

quoteFirst: I took a train in the morning, and
quoteLast: called at the rooms of Miss Manning, in Waverly Place. She had gone to dine at Delmonico's, the maid told me.
title: The Hand-Made Gentleman: A Tale of the Battles of Peace
author: Bacheller, Irving, 1859-1950

quoteFirst: Every man in the two section was hit except himself. He ordered those near him back, and remained himself out all day, from 11 a.m. till
quoteLast: with his badly wounded men. He dug shelter pits for them, and got them under cover, although fired at all the time, and finally carried one man in on his back at night, when he met him quite a long way from our trenches.
title: The Roll of Honour, Volume 1
author: Ruvigny et Raineval, Melville Henry Massue, marquis de, 1868-1921

quoteFirst: The 2d September,
quoteLast: the ship again struck and began to founder, having presently two feet water in the well. We plied our pumps till eleven; but the water increased so fast that we could continue no longer on board, and took to our boats.
title: A General History and Collection of Voyages and Travels — Volume 08
author: Kerr, Robert, 1755-1813

quoteFirst: At last,
quoteLast: , we came to the head of the valley. There we spied the Colonel and his car, on a road up on the top of the hill. We climbed up to the road, pushing a stalled rolling kitchen ahead of us.

quoteFirst: , distant about eighteen miles. This was our first march. The day was excessively hot, and Colonel Oakford received permission to march in the evening. We broke camp
quoteLast: It was a lovely moonlight night, the road was excellent, and for the first six miles the march was a delight. We marched quite leisurely, not making over two miles an hour, including rests, nevertheless the last half of the distance was very tiresome, owing to the raw and unseasoned condition of our men, and the heavy load they were carrying.
title:
War from the Inside
The Story of the 132nd Regiment Pennsylvania Volunteer Infantry in the War for the Suppression of the Rebellion, 1862-1863
author: Hitchcock, Frederick L. (Frederick Lyman)
